posts.name:
Matt Przegietka
Matt Przegietka
posts.content:
If I were to look for a job today,

I would post my projects everywhere.

Dribbble, Contra, Behance, Linkedin, X, Facebook...
... and my own website.

You know, create as big top of the funnel as I can.

Then, amplify by sharing my knowledge,
linking back to my projects.

Don't be that designer who creates a portfolio and waits.
(For the replies)

You never know where you'll catch the eye
of your next potential employer.

Be everywhere!

Ô∏è

comments.commentText: This is definitely the way to go. It‚Äôs easy to think posting on one platform is enough, but spreading it out creates so many more opportunities. How do you manage the quality of your posts across platforms while still keeping it consistent and engaging?

Tito Bohrt üß™üß´ - Sales Mad Scientist
posts.content:
During Christmas break, I committed to having a great 2025. I believe that people can influence their own luck. Perhaps luck is simply where Skill meets Opportunity. 

If you want to become a Top SDR, opportunity is coming your way too. We'll be interviewing for more Enterprise SDR roles in February 2025.

We currently have 6 proposals out for signature, and are only able to service 3 more clients in Q1.

Our February Cohort will start around Feb 17th or 24th, ramp up and get ready to be deployed to customers in April / May.

AltiSales is where good SDRs become World Class SDRs.

Excited for the year ahead.

comments.commentText: The clients pipeline should be like this xmas tree
Way to go, Tito! Your vision for 2025 is inspiring. Can't wait to see AltiSales in action with the new SDR roles. Cheers to a successful year!

posts.name:
Mark R. Koesterer
Mark R. Koesterer
posts.content:
Day 15: The Rocky Steps Challenge, Unlocking Influence

The Roommate Story

How well do the people around you truly know you? Through the power of authentic storytelling and meaningful sharing, you can create deeper connections with your fans, audience, followers, and friends.
In my real-world experience working with people, leading teams, and meeting individuals from all walks of life, I‚Äôve learned this valuable lesson: authenticity is the foundation for trust and influence.
Join me as I share a personal coaching moment‚Äîone that resonates both on and off the field. It‚Äôs a lesson for young athletes and anyone looking to grow:
Build a better you by embracing your story. Authentic sharing isn‚Äôt just a skill‚Äîit‚Äôs a way to inspire, connect, and lead.

Take a listen HERE:

Building Champions Beyond the Game

posts.name:
Sanghamitra D.
Sanghamitra D.
posts.content:
Be very choosy when deciding on people with whom to share and what to share. You may give your weapon to them to hurt you.

Be very careful.

comments.commentText: Your insight on the importance of discerning whom to trust resonates deeply. In our interconnected world, safeguarding our vulnerabilities is crucial to maintaining our well-being. Thank you for sharing such a powerful reminder.

posts.name:
Salesty - a sales community
Salesty - a sales community
posts.content:
100 CONVERSATIONS. 0 CONVERSIONS. Been there?

Let's fix it: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Listen Actively:

‚Üí 46% of buyers rate active listening, as the top skill in sales.

‚Ü≥ Listening ‚Üí Discovering pain points.

‚Ü≥ Pain points ‚Üí Personalized solutions.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Personalize Solutions:

‚Üí 77% of B2B buyers won‚Äôt purchase without a tailored solution.

‚Ü≥ Personalised solutions ‚Üí Questions from prospects.

‚Ü≥ Questions ‚Üí Objections.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Handle Objections Strategically:

‚Üí Top sales reps ask clarifying questions, 54.3% of the time when facing objections.

Objections aren‚Äôt walls‚Äîthey‚Äôre opportunities.

By asking the right questions:

‚Ü≥ You shift focus from price ‚Üí value.

‚Ü≥ You help them arrive at the solution themselves.

‚Ü≥ You build trust while uncovering pain points.

For me, "Trust > Transactions". Always.

Follow to get smarter at "Mindset ‚Üí Money".

Because, you deserve to be in the "1% Club"! Ô∏è

PS: Are you able to add to the list? Share in the comments!

posts.name:
Akansha Padmane
Akansha Padmane
posts.content:
Swiggy just dropped their 15-min food delivery app - SNACC, and here‚Äôs what caught my eye in the first scroll:

The vibe: It‚Äôs got a super fun, Gen Z-targeted feel (with meme-inspired cats, lol). It's playful and engaging!

Pasta as a category: A unique addition, especially since it‚Äôs something their competitors don‚Äôt offer. While the price point is a bit higher compared to other products, it might definitely set them apart.

Healthy salads: This category has huge potential for quick-service food delivery. The market‚Äôs massive, and adding convenience to the mix is a solid win. Can‚Äôt wait to see them expand this lineup!

Oh, and a free cookie on orders? It‚Äôs a smart touch to hook in first-time buyers.

Right now, the app‚Äôs available only in some parts of Bengaluru, so I haven‚Äôt been able to try the products yet

P.S. Speaking of Pyng‚Äîalthough talked about as a professional services app, it feels like a great move for freelancers in India, where there‚Äôs a real market gap for a convenient platform. More thoughts when it fully launches!

comments.commentText: Although Ui and major part of Ux feels great but sometimes feels clunky

posts.name:
Neel Jadhav
Neel Jadhav
posts.content:
Everyone should try making 10k.
From something that is not their job. 

It would teach them just how difficult it is to do something on your own.

It will also give them more respect for the small vendors and freelancers who are made to wait 45-60-90 days or even longer for their payments.

I get it, it's 'standard policy'.

But its impossible to wait for that long for most.
Salaries, rent, even survival depends on timely payments.

If you have influence in your org, this is one change worth fighting for.

Startups and entrepreneurs are the blood fueling our country.
We need them more than we realize.

comments.commentText: I agree Neel but so many times, we have to struggle to get our money on time. And if you do follow-up some of the executives feel offended. At times, I have given them an analogy - imagine if your salary is delayed. But the moment you say something like this, all the more they stopped answering our calls. They fail to realise that we have to run our show and pay money to our teams too.. Glad you talked about it.
Rupali Been there. An Indian client used our platform for 3 months and then declined to pay. "Jao Case kardo" were the parting words.

Neel I had a different level, I asked for my pending money, the client sent me a legal notice  
Imagine to secure that money - I will be incurring more money to fight a legal case.. Even if you are MSME, the client knows how to find a way not to pay the money..

Imagine if organizations innovated in payment policies the same way they do in product development‚Äîearly pay incentives, transparent timelines, and an ‚Äòentrepreneur-in-residence‚Äô mindset could transform how we collaborate with small businesses. Thnoughts?
Its possible, Moin. The contract dictates the payment terms. For smaller payments, I think its possible to pay faster without affecting cashflows.

posts.name:
Terrance Berland
Terrance Berland
posts.content: Could not agree more with Rob Snyder about the prioritization of sales. Have seen way too many early stage companies, particularly tech companies, burn through tens of millions of dollars and build out large product and delivery organizations with little to no prioritization for the revenue engine that is supposed to feed everything. They do this under the hopes that the ‚Äúproduct will be so compelling that it sells itself.‚Äù Reality is that sales is the hardest job most people have never done and so they just don‚Äôt understand it‚Äôs priority until it‚Äôs too late.

posts.name:
Rocky LaGrone
Rocky LaGrone
posts.content:
So this was a bust. Is anyone else beginning to think LI is a waste of time? In December, I attempted to do an experiment on LI to help not only me but all my colleagues learn a bit more about the LI algorithm and their ever-changing, confusing rules for posts. I just don't get it. LI is supposed to be a business networking tool to meet people you might have never met, generate leads, and share best practices in your field. It has turned into a confusing and often political landscape that is not much different than FB. We are not supposed to try to get meetings or introduce our services, and 90% of posts don't reach more than 10% of our followers and connections.

However, I promised to share the results, so here they are.
There were 408 views and 7 "me" comments.

I've hired and fired no less than 4 LI experts in 2024 who promised to expand my network with my ICP and generate leads with ZERO results. I'm beginning to think LI is nothing more than a waste of time.

Does anyone else feel this way?

Here is the experimental post.
